title.value: Sociotechnical Harms of Algorithmic Systems: Scoping a Taxonomy for Harm Reduction
title.justification: It is the exact title given at the top of the paper
title.quote: Sociotechnical Harms of Algorithmic Systems: Scoping a Taxonomy for Harm Reduction

extractions.description: This paper presents a taxonomy of sociotechnical harms from algorithmic systems based on a scoping review of 172 computing research articles. The taxonomy aims to help practitioners systematically consider potential harms, organized into five categories: representational, allocative, quality-of-service, interpersonal harms, and societal harms.

type.justification: The paper is based on a scoping review of 172 computing research articles, which is an empirical method.
type.quote: Based on a scoping review of computing research (n=172), we present an applied taxonomy of sociotechnical harms to support a more systematic surfacing of potential harms in algorithmic systems.

name.justification: The paper focuses on identified harms across a wide range of algorithmic technologies within computing research.
name.quote: A growing body of scholarship has identified a wide range of harms across different algorithmic technologies. However, computing research and practitioners lack a high level and synthesized overview of harms from algorithmic systems.

name.justification: The paper builds on findings from HCI to identify various harms from algorithmic systems.
name.quote: Scholars in HCI, machine learning, Science and Technology Studies (STS), and related disciplines have identified various harms from digital technologies (e.g., [9, 121, 192, 193, 207]).

name.justification: The literature review includes articles from Science and Technology Studies that discuss harms and power dynamics in algorithmic systems.
name.quote: Scholars in HCI, machine learning, Science and Technology Studies (STS), and related disciplines have identified various harms from digital technologies (e.g., [9, 121, 192, 193, 207]).
